long_description: Extract setiment of each text column.The sentiment analysis level can be document and sentence.

input_tables.name: input
input_tables.rDescription: The table defining the input text.
input_tables.description: The table defining the input text.

argument_clauses.name: TextColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input column that contains text from which to extract sentiments.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input column that contains text from which to extract sentiments.

argument_clauses.name: Accumulate
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the input columns to copy to the output table.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the names of the input columns to copy to the output table.

argument_clauses.name: InputLanguage
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the language of the input text:  en (English, the default),  zh_CN (Simplified Chinese),  zh_TW (Traditional Chinese)
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the language of the input text:  en (English, the default),  zh_CN (Simplified Chinese),  zh_TW (Traditional Chinese)

argument_clauses.name: ModelFile
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the model type and file. The default model type is dictionary. If you omit this argument or specify dictionary without dict_file, then you must specify a dictionary table with alias 'dict'. If you specify both dict and dict_file, then whenever their words conflict, dict has higher priority. The dict_file must be a text file in which each line contains only a sentiment word, a space, and the opinion score of the sentiment word. If you specify classification:model_file, model_file must be the name of a model file generated and installed on the database by the function aa.sentiment.train. Note: Before running the function, add the location of dict_file or model_file to the user/session default search path.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the model type and file. The default model type is dictionary. If you omit this argument or specify dictionary without dict_file, then you must specify a dictionary table with alias 'dict'. If you specify both dict and dict_file, then whenever their words conflict, dict has higher priority. The dict_file must be a text file in which each line contains only a sentiment word, a space, and the opinion score of the sentiment word. If you specify classification:model_file, model_file must be the name of a model file generated and installed on the database by the function “TrainSentimentExtractor” on page 780. Note: Before running the function, add the location of dict_file or model_file to the user/session default search path.

argument_clauses.name: AnalysisType
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the level of analysis—whether to analyze each document (the default) or each sentence.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the level of analysis—whether to analyze each document (the default) or each sentence.

argument_clauses.name: Priority
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the highest priority when returning results:  NEGATIVE_RECALL: Give highest priority to negative results, including those with lowerconfidence sentiment classifications (maximizes the number of negative results returned), NEGATIVE_PRECISION: Give highest priority to negative results with high-confidence sentiment classifications. POSITIVE_RECALL: Give highest priority to positive results, including those with lowerconfidence sentiment classifications (maximizes the number of positive results returned). POSITIVE_PRECISION: Give highest priority to positive results with high-confidence sentiment classifications. NONE: Give all results the same priority.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the highest priority when returning results:  NEGATIVE_RECALL: Give highest priority to negative results, including those with lowerconfidence sentiment classifications (maximizes the number of negative results returned), NEGATIVE_PRECISION: Give highest priority to negative results with high-confidence sentiment classifications. POSITIVE_RECALL: Give highest priority to positive results, including those with lowerconfidence sentiment classifications (maximizes the number of positive results returned). POSITIVE_PRECISION: Give highest priority to positive results with high-confidence sentiment classifications. NONE: Give all results the same priority.

argument_clauses.name: OutputType
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the kind of results to return: POSITIVE: Return only results with positive sentiments. NEGATIVE: Return only results with negative sentiments. ALL: Return all results (default)
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the kind of results to return: POSITIVE: Return only results with positive sentiments. NEGATIVE: Return only results with negative sentiments. ALL: Return all results (default)

argument_clauses.name: SequenceInputBy
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the LIST_VECTOR of column(s) that uniquely identifies each row of the input argument INPUT_ARG_NAME. The argument is used to ensure deterministic results for functions which produce results that vary from run to run.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the input column(s) that uniquely identify each row of input table. The format is 'input1:c1' where input1 refers to the alias used by the input table that contains such column named c1.
